an5.233:4.1: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities beautifies the monastery.
an5.233:4.3: They’re ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, and accomplished in appropriate behavior and means of collecting alms. Seeing danger in the slightest flaw, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5.233:4.4: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and understanding them with right view.
an5.233:4.5: They’re a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.
an5.233:4.6: They’re able to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire those who approach them with a Dharma talk.
an5.233:4.7: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5.233:4.8: A resident mendicant with these five qualities beautifies the monastery.”
